message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: How digital media drive affective polarization through partisan sorting
Paper Abstract: Politics has in recent decades entered an era of intense polarization. Explanations have implicated digital media, with the so-called echo chamber remaining a dominant causal hypothesis despite growing challenge by empirical evidence. This paper suggests that this mounting evidence provides not only reason to reject the echo chamber hypothesis but also the foundation for an alternative causal mechanism. To propose such a mechanism, the paper draws on the literatures on affective polarization, digital media, and opinion dynamics. From the affective polarization literature, we follow the move from seeing polarization as diverging issue positions to rooted in sorting: an alignment of differences which is effectively dividing the electorate into two increasingly homogeneous megaparties. To explain the rise in sorting, the paper draws on opinion dynamics and digital media research to present a model which essentially turns the echo chamber on its head: it is not isolation from opposing views that drives polarization but precisely the fact that digital media bring us to interact outside our local bubble. When individuals interact locally, the outcome is a stable plural patchwork of cross-cutting conflicts. By encouraging nonlocal interaction, digital media drive an alignment of conflicts along partisan lines, thus effacing the counterbalancing effects of local heterogeneity. The result is polarization, even if individual interaction leads to convergence. The model thus suggests that digital media polarize through partisan sorting, creating a maelstrom in which more and more identities, beliefs, and cultural preferences become drawn into an all-encompassing societal division.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Political polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization"},{"title":"Political polarization in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"File:The IRA, Social Media and Political Polarization in the United States, 2012-2018.pdf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_IRA,_Social_Media_and_Political_Polarization_in_the_United_States,_2012-2018.pdf"},{"title":"Political polarization in Turkey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_Turkey"},{"title":"Negative partisanship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_partisanship"},{"title":"Partisan sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_sorting"},{"title":"August 2023 Ohio Issue 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_2023_Ohio_Issue_1"},{"title":"2025 North Macedonian local elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_North_Macedonian_local_elections"},{"title":"Ground News - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ground_News"},{"title":"Millennial politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millennial_politics"}]

## Political Polarization Overview

I found comprehensive information about political polarization from your web search. Here's what the results show:

### Definition and Core Concepts

Political polarization is the divergence of political attitudes away from the center, towards ideological extremes.(no content)Scholars distinguish between ideological polarization (differences between policy positions) and affective polarization (an emotional dislike and distrust of political out-groups).

### Key Types of Polarization

Political scientists distinguish between two levels: elite polarization, which focuses on the polarization of political elites like party organizers and elected officials, and mass polarization, which focuses on the polarization of the general public and electorate.

### Characteristics in Two-Party Systems

In a two-party system, a polarized legislature has two important characteristics: first, there is little-to-no ideological overlap between members of the two parties, and second, almost all conflict over legislation and policies is split across a broad ideological divide.

### United States Context

Polarization has increased since the 1970s, with rapid increases during the 2000s onwards. According to the Pew Research Center, members of both parties who have unfavorable opinions of the opposing party have doubled since 1994, while those who have very unfavorable opinions of the opposing party are at record highs as of 2022.

### Related Phenomenon: Negative Partisanship

Negative partisanship is the tendency of some voters to form their political opinions primarily in opposition to political parties they dislike, whereas traditional partisanship involves supporting the policy positions of one's own party.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Political Polarization Overview

I found comprehensive information about political polarization from your web search. Here's what the results show:

### Definition and Core Concepts

Political polarization is the divergence of political attitudes away from the center, towards ideological extremes.(no content)Scholars distinguish between ideological polarization (differences between policy positions) and affective polarization (an emotional dislike and distrust of political out-groups).

### Key Types of Polarization

Political scientists distinguish between two levels: elite polarization, which focuses on the polarization of political elites like party organizers and elected officials, and mass polarization, which focuses on the polarization of the general public and electorate.

### Characteristics in Two-Party Systems

In a two-party system, a polarized legislature has two important characteristics: first, there is little-to-no ideological overlap between members of the two parties, and second, almost all conflict over legislation and policies is split across a broad ideological divide.

### United States Context

Polarization has increased since the 1970s, with rapid increases during the 2000s onwards. According to the Pew Research Center, members of both parties who have unfavorable opinions of the opposing party have doubled since 1994, while those who have very unfavorable opinions of the opposing party are at record highs as of 2022.

### Related Phenomenon: Negative Partisanship

Negative partisanship is the tendency of some voters to form their political opinions primarily in opposition to political parties they dislike, whereas traditional partisanship involves supporting the policy positions of one's own party.

## Opinion Dynamics

Based on the search results, here's an overview of opinion dynamics:

### Definition and Scope

Mathematical models of social learning aim to model opinion dynamics in social networks.(no content)These models consider settings where people (agents) hold beliefs or opinions about various matters such as product quality, policy effectiveness, or news reliability.

### Key Research Questions

Some of the main questions in the literature include whether social learning effectively aggregates scattered information and whether consensus beliefs match the true state of the world, as well as how influential media sources, politicians, and prominent agents can be in shaping network-wide belief formation.

### Major Models

**DeGroot Learning**: According to the DeGroot model, each agent takes a weighted average of their neighbors' opinions at each step to update their own belief.

**Sznajd Model**: The Sznajd model is a sociophysics model introduced in 2000 to gain fundamental understanding about opinion dynamics, with the principle that if two people share the same opinion, their neighbors will start to agree with them.

### Applications

The DeGroot learning model has been used in physics, computer science and most widely in the theory of social networks. Opinion dynamics research has broader applications to understanding how beliefs form and spread within groups and societies.

Here are the search results for "Digital media":

## Definition and Overview

Digital media refers to mediums of digitized information broadcast through a screen and/or a speaker.(no content)This includes text, audio, video, and graphics transmitted over the internet for consumption on digital devices.

## Examples

Examples of digital media include software, digital images, web pages and websites, social media, digital data and databases, digital audio such as MP3, electronic documents and electronic books.

## Impact on Society

Combined with the Internet and personal computing, digital media has caused disruptive innovation in publishing, journalism, public relations, entertainment, education, commerce and politics.(no content)The ubiquity of digital media and its effects on society suggest that we are at the start of a new era in industrial history, called the Information Age, perhaps leading to a paperless society in which all media are produced and consumed on computers.

## Historical Context

It is estimated that in the year 1986 less than 1% of the world's media storage capacity was digital and in 2007 it was already 94%. The year 2002 is assumed to be the year when human kind was able to store more information in digital than in analog media (the "beginning of the digital age").

Web search results for query: "Partisan sorting"

Links: [{"title":"Partisan sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_sorting"},{"title":"Political polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization"},{"title":"Matthew Levendusky - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Levendusky"},{"title":"Partial sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial_sorting"},{"title":"Category:Politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Politics"},{"title":"Soviet partisans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Partisans"},{"title":"Cook Partisan Voting Index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cook_Partisan_Voting_Index"},{"title":"Political polarization in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Jewish partisans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jewish_partisans"},{"title":"Partisan (politics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_(politics)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about partisan sorting:

## Definition

Partisan sorting is an effect in politics in which voters sort themselves into parties that match their ideology.(no content)It refers to the extent to which the electorate "sorts" or identifies with a party based on their ideological, racial, religious, gender, or other demographic characteristics.

## Key Distinction from Polarization

Partisan sorting is distinct from political polarization, which is where partisans subscribe to increasingly extreme positions.(no content)As political scientist Nolan McCarty explains, "party sorting can account for the increased differences across partisans even if the distribution of attitudes in the population remains unchanged or moves uniformly in one direction or the other."

## Historical Example

The gap between the Democratic Party and Republican Party on views towards immigrants strengthening the country with hard work and talents has widened from a 2-point gap in 1994 to a 42-point gap in 2017.(no content)A reasonable explanation is that of partisan sorting: those who are pro-immigrant shifted into the Democratic party and immigration-restrictions have shifted towards the Republican party.

## Geographic Sorting

A form of partisan sorting is geographic sorting, which alleges that people decide to move into communities that match their party.(no content)Research by political scientists in 2012 found that people prefer to relocate to areas with copartisans, though it was unsure if it was a central or secondary factor.

## Academic Debate

There are different scholarly perspectives on the relative importance of sorting versus polarization in explaining political divisions in the United States.

Partisan sorting is an effect in politics in which voters sort themselves into parties that match their ideology.(no content)It refers to the extent to which the electorate "sorts" or identifies with a party based on their ideological, racial, religious, gender, or other demographic characteristics.

## Key Distinction from Polarization

Partisan sorting is distinct from political polarization, which is where partisans subscribe to increasingly extreme positions.(no content)As political scientist Nolan McCarty explains, "party sorting can account for the increased differences across partisans even if the distribution of attitudes in the population remains unchanged or moves uniformly in one direction or the other."

## Historical Example

The gap between the Democratic Party and Republican Party on views towards immigrants strengthening the country with hard work and talents has widened from a 2-point gap in 1994 to a 42-point gap in 2017.(no content)A reasonable explanation is that of partisan sorting: those who are pro-immigrant shifted into the Democratic party and immigration-restrictions have shifted towards the Republican party.

## Geographic Sorting

A form of partisan sorting is geographic sorting, which alleges that people decide to move into communities that match their party.(no content)Research by political scientists in 2012 found that people prefer to relocate to areas with copartisans, though it was unsure if it was a central or secondary factor.

## Academic Debate

There are different scholarly perspectives on the relative importance of sorting versus polarization in explaining political divisions in the United States.

Web search results for query: "Echo chamber internet"

Links: [{"title":"Echo chamber (media) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echo_chamber_(media)"},{"title":"Filter bubble - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filter_bubble"},{"title":"Talk:Echo chamber (media) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Echo_chamber_(media)"},{"title":"Echo chamber - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echo_chamber"},{"title":"Google's Ideological Echo Chamber - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google's_Ideological_Echo_Chamber"},{"title":"Criticism of Google - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_tax_avoidance"},{"title":"Institute for Strategic Dialogue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_for_Strategic_Dialogue"},{"title":"Echo Chamber (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echo_Chamber_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Talk:Google's Ideological Echo Chamber/Archive 3 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Google's_Ideological_Echo_Chamber/Archive_3"},{"title":"Echo (communications protocol) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echo_(communications_protocol)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about echo chambers on the internet:

## Definition and Concept

An echo chamber is a metaphorical description of a situation in which beliefs are amplified or reinforced by communication and repetition inside a closed system.(no content)The term is a metaphor based on an acoustic echo chamber, in which sounds reverberate in a hollow enclosure.

## How Echo Chambers Work

The echo chamber effect occurs online when a harmonious group of people amalgamate and develop tunnel vision, and participants in online discussions may find their opinions constantly echoed back to them, which reinforces their individual belief systems due to the declining exposure to others' opinions.(no content)People are receiving their news online more rapidly through less traditional sources, such as Facebook, Google, and Twitter, and these and many other social platforms and online media outlets have established personalized algorithms intended to cater specific information to individuals' online feeds.

## Related Concept: Filter Bubbles

Filter bubbles are implicit mechanisms of pre-selected personalization, where a user's media consumption is created by personalized algorithms; the content a user sees is filtered through an AI-driven algorithm that reinforces their existing beliefs and preferences, potentially excluding contrary or diverse perspectives.

## Effects and Concerns

This sort of feedback regulation may increase political and social polarization and extremism, and can lead to users aggregating into homophilic clusters within social networks, which contributes to group polarization.(no content)However, some studies have suggested that the effects of echo chambers are weaker than often assumed.

Web search results for query: "Affective polarization"

Links: [{"title":"Political polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization"},{"title":"Political polarization in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Group polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_polarization"},{"title":"Intellectual humility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intellectual_humility"},{"title":"David Broockman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Broockman"},{"title":"Affective spectrum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_disorders"},{"title":"Polarization (waves) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polarization_(waves)"},{"title":"Empathising–systemising theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empathizing-systemizing_theory"},{"title":"Why We're Polarized - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Why_We're_Polarized"},{"title":"Polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polarization"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about affective polarization:

## Definition

Affective polarization refers to the extent to which the electorate "dislikes" or "distrusts" those from other parties. It is distinct from other forms of political division: scholars distinguish between ideological polarization (differences between the policy positions) and affective polarization (an emotional dislike and distrust of political out-groups).

## Characteristics and Effects

Affective polarization refers to the phenomenon where individuals' feelings and emotions towards members of their own political party or group become more positive, while their feelings towards members of the opposing party or group become more negative. This can lead to increased hostility and a lack of willingness to compromise or work together with people who hold different political views.(no content)Affective polarization is closely related to political tribalism and "us-them" thinking.(no content)Affective polarization may lead to aggressive attitudes and behaviors toward members of other ideological groups within the same country. Extreme affective polarization may even lead to dangerous consequences like societal disintegration and ideological sorting.

## Current Trends

Researchers have identified an increase in affective polarization among the United States electorate, and report that hostility and discrimination towards the opposing political party has increased dramatically over time. Additionally, some research suggests that affective polarization is growing more rapidly than ideological polarization and perhaps even driving it.

## Potential Solutions

Affective polarization can be reduced by various means, such as feeling sadness together as a group (which often happens during Memorial Days). A high prevalence of respectful discussions with political others may also reduce affective polarization by increasing political tolerance and inter-party trust.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed all tasks. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification**: **Contribution** - This paper proposes a novel causal mechanism explaining how digital media drive affective polarization through partisan sorting, replacing the dominant echo chamber hypothesis.

**Key Triples Extracted** (6 total):

1. **Political polarization** (concept, uses) - The core phenomenon the paper addresses
2. **Affective polarization** (concept, uses) - The specific type of polarization (emotional dislike) the paper focuses on
3. **Partisan sorting** (concept, proposes) - The novel mechanism the paper proposes as the driver of polarization
4. **Echo chamber (media)** (concept, uses) - The existing hypothesis the paper challenges and builds upon
5. **Digital media** (tool, uses) - The platforms enabling nonlocal interactions that drive partisan alignment
6. **Opinion dynamics** (concept, uses) - The theoretical framework for modeling opinion evolution

**Validation Result**: ✅ **PASSED** - All 6 triples are properly formatted with valid Wikipedia URLs, correct entity types, and appropriate relations (5 "uses", 1 "proposes").

Sources:
- [Political polarization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization)
- [Partisan sorting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_sorting)
- [Echo chamber (media)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echo_chamber_(media))
- [Digital media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_media)
- [Mathematical models of social learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_models_of_social_learning)
